title: Ticket #43: Path -vs- PATH on Windows?
remarks:
2009-Jan-20 15:51:04 by tannenba:
Ian Alderman ( mailto:ialderman@cyclecomputing.com ) conjectures on condor-users:

The addition of the function getWindowsEnvironmentString (in env.cpp, called from daemon_core.cpp) may have a role. This function reorders the environment variables; could reordering be sufficient to result in the funky behavior?

2009-Jan-22 14:21:29 by gquinn:
This appears to be a bug that has always existed. It must have surfaced in 7.2.0 for some users as a result of the getWindowsEnvironmentString work I did earlier. In other words, I fixed a bug without fixing its anti-bug ;)

The problem is that onn Windows, environment variable names are case insensitive, but our Env object is case sensitive.

Fixing this is more subtle than it may seem, because of our ability to cross-submit. I decided to keep the hash table in the Env object case-sensitive, but on Windows we additionally maintain an STL set that ignores case. With this additional data structure, when Env::getWindowsEnvironmentString is called, we can produce an environment that:

  • is sorted, as Windows requires
  • does not contain any duplicate variable names when case is ignored

When multiple variable names that differ only in case exist in the Env object's hash table, the set ensures that the last one to be inserted "wins".
